sentence: Embattled social media company Twitter (TWTR), often compared to MySpace, faces an uphill battle to turn things around in 2017.
Co-founder and CEO Jack Dorsey, meanwhile, is not leaving things up to fate to determine his company's success.
Unlike Facebook (FB), which brings friends and families together, or LinkedIn which connects professionals, Twitter's utility and purpose has long been a question mark.
Dorsey, who spend the bulk of 2016 searching under every rock for revenue and earnings growth, is determined to give users what they want.
The CEO last week used the platform to poll its user base with the above question.
As of this writing, Dorsey's inquiry has generated more than 7,000 replies.
And not surprisingly, the most requested feature is for Twitter to add an edit function.
After all, it's hard to be witty when your tweet contains grammatical and spelling errors.
And for Twitter, allowing users the ability to fix their mistakes -- while it may seem small -- could be a big step helping Twitter realize one important utility: factual and accurate tweets.
From all of the user responses, Dorsey narrowed down the requests into four groups.
Aside from the need to edit tweets, users want Twitter to cut down on abuse, while requesting for increased topics and interests and conversations.
Cutting down on abuse and hate speech has already been high on Twitter's priority list.

The company, which was the subject of numerous M&A speculation last year, was reportedly passed on by both Salesforce.com (CRM) and Disney (DIS) for the level of harassment that occurs on the platform.
The company's failure to control these issues and make the necessary improvements have been cited as reason for the stalled user growth.
Happy users makes for increased engagement.
Higher engagements makes advertisers more willing to spend on the platform.
In other words, Dorsey has his priorities together.
To what extent he can deliver on these improvements and whether they will increase Twitter's value remain to be seen.
But assuming Dorsey, though he didn't promise to deliver on all the requests, is successful at just two or even three of them, Twitter could be on its way to a successful year.

Beyond his focus on growing Twitter's video capabilities, Dorsey has already introduced features such as Muted Words, which gives users the ability to better control the tweets they see and don't want to see.
In other words, Twitter is heading in the right direction.
And we could one day look back at Dorsey's tweet last week and say this was when it all came together.
